semantic_title: Sequencing Rules for Place of Occurrence, Activity, and Status Codes
section_path: Chapter 20: External Causes of Morbidity > d. Place of Occurrence, Activity, and Status Codes Used with other External Cause Code

content.full_text: When applicable, place of occurrence, activity, and external cause status codes are sequenced after the main external cause code(s). Regardless of the number of external cause codes assigned, generally there should be only one place of occurrence code, one activity code, and one external cause status code assigned to an encounter. However, in the rare instance that a new injury occurs during hospitalization, an additional place of occurrence code may be assigned. (Evidence: pg no: 89, L60-L65)
content.summary: Place of occurrence, activity, and status codes are sequenced after main external cause codes, with generally one of each type per encounter, except for new injuries during hospitalization (Evidence: pg no: 89, L60-L65)
key_concepts: Sequence after main external cause codes (Evidence: pg no: 89, L62)
Generally one place of occurrence code per encounter (Evidence: pg no: 89, L63-L64)
Generally one activity code per encounter (Evidence: pg no: 89, L63-L64)
Generally one external cause status code per encounter (Evidence: pg no: 89, L63-L64)
Exception for new injuries during hospitalization (Evidence: pg no: 89, L64-L65)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Place of occurrence, activity, and status codes sequenced after main external cause codes (Evidence: pg no: 89, L62)
detailed_rules.explanation: These supplementary external cause codes provide additional context and should be sequenced after the primary external cause codes that describe the actual cause and intent (Evidence: pg no: 89, L60-L62)
detailed_rules.applies_to: Place of occurrence, activity, and status codes

detailed_rules.rule_text: Generally one each of place of occurrence, activity, and status codes per encounter (Evidence: pg no: 89, L63-L64)
detailed_rules.explanation: Regardless of how many main external cause codes are assigned, typically only one place, one activity, and one status code should be used per encounter (Evidence: pg no: 89, L63-L64)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Additional place of occurrence code may be assigned for new injury during hospitalization (Evidence: pg no: 89, L64-L65)
detailed_rules.explanation: The rare exception to the one-code rule occurs when a patient sustains a new injury while hospitalized, allowing for an additional place of occurrence code (Evidence: pg no: 89, L64-L65)

workflow_steps: Step 1: Assign main external cause codes first
Step 2: Add place of occurrence code after main external cause codes
Step 3: Add activity code after place of occurrence
Step 4: Add status code after activity code
Step 5: Verify only one of each supplementary code type (except rare hospital injury exception)

code_ranges.range: Place of occurrence, activity, and status codes
code_ranges.description: Supplementary external cause codes for additional context (Evidence: pg no: 89, L60-L62)
code_ranges.requirement: Sequence after main external cause codes
usage_rules: One of each type per encounter generally (Evidence: pg no: 89, L63-L64)
Exception for new hospital injuries (Evidence: pg no: 89, L64-L65)

coding_scenarios.scenario: Patient falls off ladder at work while painting, sustains multiple injuries
coding_scenarios.documentation_example: Employee fell from ladder while painting at construction site, sustained head injury and arm fracture
step_by_step: Step 1: Code primary diagnoses (head injury, arm fracture)
Step 2: Code main external cause (fall from ladder)
Step 3: Code place of occurrence (construction site) after main external cause
Step 4: Code activity (painting) after place of occurrence
Step 5: Code status (employee) after activity code

correct_coding.sequencing: Diagnoses first, then main external cause, then place/activity/status
correct_coding.rationale: Supplementary external cause codes sequenced after main external cause codes to provide complete context (Evidence: pg no: 89, L60-L62)

incorrect_coding.code: Place/activity/status codes before main external cause
incorrect_coding.rationale: Supplementary codes must follow main external cause codes
incorrect_coding.common_mistake: Incorrect sequencing of external cause code types

warnings: Don't sequence supplementary codes before main external cause codes (Evidence: pg no: 89, L62)
best_practices: Use only one of each supplementary code type per encounter (Evidence: pg no: 89, L63-L64)
Sequence supplementary codes after main external cause codes (Evidence: pg no: 89, L62)
common_mistakes: Using multiple place/activity/status codes per encounter (Evidence: pg no: 89, L63-L64)
Incorrect sequencing of external cause code types (Evidence: pg no: 89, L62)
tips: Remember the exception for new hospital injuries (Evidence: pg no: 89, L64-L65)
implementation_notes: Sequencing provides logical flow from cause to context
clinical_context: Complete external cause documentation supports comprehensive injury analysis
